chapter: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question: Question 2: Enzyme deficiency in which of the following pathways can cause hemolysis?
questions.explanation:
Enzyme deficiency in the glycolytic pathway can cause hemolysis. The following enzyme deficiencies can cause hemolysis: In the glycolytic pathway: • Pyruvate kinase deficiency • Hexokinase deficiency In the HMP shunt pathway: 365 
Sold by @itachibot • G6PD deficiency • Glutathione synthetase deficiency Note: Orotic aciduria causes megaloblastic anaemia.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question: Question 3: What is the normal reticulocyte count?
questions.explanation: Normal reticulocyte count is 0.5–1.5% of total red cells. Causes of increased reticulocyte count: • Hemolytic anaemia • Acute and chronic blood loss Causes of decreased reticulocyte count: • Iron deficiency anaemia • Megaloblastic anaemia • Aplastic anaemia • Anaemia of chronic diseases • Myelodysplastic syndromes
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is false about reticulocytes?

options.c: They are larger in size than red cell

questions.explanation:
Reticulocytes are red cell precursors, which are non-nucleated. They have blue-red polychromatophilic cytoplasm due to the presence of a reticular (mesh-like) 
network of ribosomal RNA. They can be visualized using supravital stains like methylene blue 
and brilliant cresyl blue, which stain the ribosomal RNA. Reticulocytosis (increased reticulocytes) indicates effective erythropoiesis i.e. good bone marrow 
response to anaemia. It is seen in: • Hemolytic anaemias • Acute blood loss Reticulocytopenia (decreased reticulocytes) indicates ineffective erythropoiesis i.e. poor bone 
marrow response to anaemia. It is seen in: • Chemotherapy • Aplastic anaemia • Bone marrow malignancy • Anaemia of chronic disease • Iron-deficiency anaemia • Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency 366 
Sold by @itachibot The peripheral smear shows reticulocytosis and spherocytosis seen in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question:
Question 5: A 25-year-old woman had severe blood loss during delivery 2-days ago. Her current 
hemoglobin is 5 gm/dL and reticulocyte count is 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte 
count?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the corrected reticulocyte count is 3. It is given by the following formula: Corrected reticulocyte count = Reticulocyte count × (patient's hemoglobin or hematocrit  standard 
hemoglobin or hematocrit) So, in this case, the corrected reticulocyte count = 9×5/15 = 9/3 = 3 This formula corrects for hemoglobin. It will show you if the patient is making enough 
reticulocytes for the degree of anemia present. As the hemoglobin drops, reticulocytes increase 
from the normal range of 0.5–2.0%. The standard reference range of hemoglobin concentration in females is 12-15 g/dl. Accordingly, in 
this scenario, corrected reticulocyte count would range between 3-3.75%. So, the best answer to 
this question remains option C. Absolute reticulocyte count is the percentage of red cells that are reticulocytes (normal is about 
0.5 – 2.0%). However, it does not reflect the fact that as the hemoglobin drops, there should be 
more reticulocytes, percentage-wise (for example, at a hemoglobin of 5, you should have a much 
higher percentage of reticulocytes than you should at a hemoglobin of 10). To take this into 
account, we use corrected reticulocyte count. Reticulocyte Index = Corrected reticulocyte count / maturation factor This corrects for the longer life span of prematurely released reticulocytes in the blood which is a 
phenomenon of increased red blood cell production. 367 
Sold by @itachibot Hematocrit 
Maturation fact 
or  35% 
1.0 35% > Hct 
25% 1.5 25% > Hct 
20% 2.0 < 20% 
2.5
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question:
Question 6: In a patient with microcytic hypochromic anaemia, red cell distribution width was measured. 
What is this parameter used to identify?
questions.explanation:
Red cell distribution width (RDW) deals with anisocytosis of RBCs. It refers to the unequal size of 
the RBCs. Normal values are: • RDW-SD (Standard deviation) - 39-46 fL • RDW-CV (Coefficient of variation) - 11.6-14.6% RDW is of great use in two clinical situations. They are: • To differentiate between thalassemia and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) • Thalassemia - the RBCs are small (low MCV) and of uniform size (normal RDW) • IDA - the RBCs are small (low MCV) but vary greatly in size (high RDW). • To diagnose dimorphic anaemia (anaemia due to both iron and vitamin B12 deficiency) • High RDW • Normal MCV
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not increased in intravascular hemolysis?
questions.explanation:
Haptoglobin is decreased in intravascular hemolysis. Types of hemolysis based on location: • Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessels • Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs via macrophages of the reticuloendothelial 
system in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes Features of intravascular hemolysis are: • Decreased haptoglobin • Increased lactate dehydrogenase • Hemoglobinemia 368 
Sold by @itachibot • Hemoglobinuria • Hemosiderinuria • Methemoglobinemia • Methemoglobinuria • Indirect hyperbilirubinemia
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following does not cause intravascular hemolysis?
questions.explanation:
Thalassemia causes extravascular hemolysis. Causes of intravascular hemolysis: • Mechanical injury • Trauma caused by cardiac valves • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular 
coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura ) • Repetitive physical trauma • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction) • Hemolytic disease of the newborn • Transfusion reaction • Drug-induced • Infections of red blood cells • Malaria • Babesiosis • Exogenous toxic factors - Clostridial sepsis 369 
Sold by @itachibot Causes of extravascular hemolysis: • Hereditary spherocytosis • Thalassemia • Sickle cell anaemia Causes of both intravascular and extravascular: • G6PD deficiency • Autoimmune hemolytic anaemia
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following pairs of mutation and involved genes describes paroxysmal nocturnal 
hemoglobinuria?
questions.explanation:
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in 
the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA). This gene codes for an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated 
complement regulatory proteins. It is the only hemolytic anaemia caused by an acquired genetic 
defect. PNH blood cells are deficient in 3 GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity: • Decay Accelerating Factor or CD55 • Membrane Inhibitor of Reactive Lysis or CD59 • C˜-binding protein CD59, a potent inhibitor of C3 convertase, prevents the spontaneous activation of the alternative 
complement pathway. Red cells deficient in these GPI-linked factors are abnormally susceptible to 
lysis or injury by C5b-C9 membrane attack complex of the complement system. 370 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following cells are involved in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.explanation:
All three cell lines, RBCs, WBCs, and platelets are affected in paroxysmal nocturnal 
hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH occurs from acquired mutations in the gene PIGA which affect GPI-linked proteins. 
These causative mutations occur in a hematopoietic stem cell. Hence, all of its clonal progeny, i.e., 
red cells, white cells, and platelets, are deficient in GPI-linked proteins. Clinical features of PNH include: • Intravascular hemoglobinuria - cola-colored urine • Pancytopenia + hypercellular bone marrow • Thrombosis (if hepatic vein involved  Budd–Chiari syndrome)
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question:
Question 11: A 23-year-old man with pancytopenia is suspected to have PNH. Which of the following 
findings is inconsistent with this condition?
questions.explanation:
In PNH, the leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased. Alkaline phosphatase activity is found predominantly in mature segmented neutrophils. LAP 
score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each 
neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages 
of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP. Increased LAP 
Decreased LAP CMLPNHSickle cell ane 
mia Leukemoid reactionPregnanc 
yPolycythemia veraHodgkin's 
disease
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following is most likely the cause of death in a patient with paroxysmal 
nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.explanation:
Among the following, Budd-Chiari Syndrome is the most likely the cause of death in a patient with 
paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Thrombosis (particularly venous thrombosis) is the leading cause of disease-related death in 
patients with PNH. 40% of PNH patients suffer from venous thrombosis, which commonly affects 
the hepatic, portal, or cerebral veins. The pathophysiology of thrombosis in PNH is not completely understood, but two main 
mechanisms may be responsible: • Nitric oxide (NO) is absorbed by free hemoglobin (which is released during hemolysis). • Endothelial damage caused by the C5-9 membrane attack complex (due to deficiency of CD59). 371 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question:
Question 13: Flow cytometric analysis in a patient with pancytopenia shows a deficiency of GPI-linked 
proteins on blood cells. Which of the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The deficiency of GPI linked proteins on blood cells is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal 
hemoglobinuria (PNH). Cryoglobulinemia is not a complication of this condition. Thrombosis is the leading cause of disease-related death in individuals with paroxysmal nocturnal 
hemoglobinuria (PNH). About 5% to 10% of patients eventually develop acute myeloid 
leukemia (AML) or myelodysplastic syndrome.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question: Question 14: What is the gold standard for the diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?
questions.explanation:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of PNH is flow cytometry. It provides a sensitive means for 
detecting red cells that are deficient in GPI-linked proteins such as CD59. Investigations in PNH include: • Flow cytometry (gold standard) - deficiency of CD59 and CD55 • Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation • Bone marrow biopsy - • Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentations • Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow • Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosis
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis

questions.question:
Question 15: A 37-year-old man presents with a history of dark coloured urine in the morning for 2 
months. His lab investigations and flow cytometry are given below. What is the curative 
therapy for this condition? 363 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of PNH (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria). The 
curative therapy for this condition is a hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Pancytopenia is seen in this condition. Flow cytometry shows 2 populations of red cells: • Marked red in the left lower quadrant - deficient in both CD55 and CD59, characteristic of PNH. • Marked black in the right upper quadrant - CD55+ and CD59+ cells from the residual normal 
hematopoietic cells Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that can be used in PNH. It prevents the conversion of C5 
to C5a and reduces hemolysis. Immunosuppressive drugs are sometimes beneficial for those with evidence of marrow aplasia. Note: FDA has approved the following drugs for treatment of adults with PNH: • Ravulizumab injection, a long-acting C-5 complement inhibitor • Pegcetacoplan, which acts by binding to complement protein C3 and increasing hemoglobin 
concentration 372 
Sold by @itachibot Extravascular Hemolysis
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Hemolysis and Intravascular Hemolysis
